FacilityName: Ashland Aqualon Functional In- Kenedy, Texas Plant

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Propylene Oxide emergency stop and sensor calibration

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Ashland, Incorporated purchased Hercules, Incorporated in November of 2008.  Hercules, Incorporated still, owns and operates the Kenedy Texas plant under the name Ashland Aqualon Functional Ingredients.  The guar manufacturing facility is located at One Mill Street, Kenedy, Karnes County, Texas.  The plant processes include bulk storage of guar splits, alteration by chemical addition, and grinding.  Propylene oxide is stored in a bulk storage tank, with tanker truck deliveries on approximately a bi-weekly schedule.  The Risk Management Plan has been developed in accordance with "Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions" under 40 CFR part 68.

The Kenedy Plant uses Propylene Oxide above the threshold and is subject to Program 3 requirements.  Propylene Oxide is a listed regulated substance used in the P80 process and in the pilot plant.  RMP regulations define a Program 3 process to be one that has the potential for off-site impacts from a release and is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program or is classified in one of nine Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) codes.

The Offsite Consequences Analysis

The 2009 RMP update uses the ALOHA program to calculate distance to the Toxic End Point for the worst case and alternative case scenarios.  MARPLOT is used to calculate the population within the area plotted by ALOHA.  There is a difference from the original offsite consequence models which used RMP COMP to calculate the Toxic End Point of both scenarios.  Because of the difference in the Toxic End Point distances, there is a corresponding difference in population estimates.  Overall population for the City of Kenedy remains unchanged from the previous RMP submittal.  One of the factors causing the difference is that ALOHA limited the Worst Case Scenario release duration to 1 hour as compared to the RMP COMP release duration of 10 hours.  The primary purpose of revisiting the offsite consequence models was to use a different

ground roughness category as suggested by an EPA Audit.  The 2004 scenarios used rural whereas the 2009 uses urban/forest to allow for the buildings located in the City of Kenedy located just to the north west of the plant.   

The Accidental Release and Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Ashland, Incorporated is dedicated to providing a safe and healthful environment for employees, customers, and communities.  The Ashland Aqualon Functional Ingredients facility remains an OSHA VPP Star site.  This facility complies with all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  All management practices associated with Responsible Care Program compliance are reviewed frequently to assure all provisions are in place and operational.  Detailed emergency plans are in place at the plant.  HAZMAT recertification is conducted annually utilizing TEEX (an extension of Texas A&M University) and annual drills are held to involve the entire plant.  

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled

Propylene oxide is handled in the bulk chemical storage and unloading area.  Typically, propylene oxide is delivered to the plant biweekly in tanker trucks with carry approximately 44,000 pounds each.  The truck is parked in the unloading area using procedures that assure the chemical holding portion of the truck is within the protected area.  The protected area has a trench around the perimeter, which is intended to catch any releases of propylene oxide.  The trench drains to a concrete lined neutralization pit where it can be pumped to another container or otherwise controlled.

The truck is hooked up to the unloading system using dry disconnect, 2-inch, stainless steel wire wrapped, flex hoses.  Dry disconnect hoses prevent release of chemical as the hoses are connected and disconnected.  Propylene oxide is pumped from the truck to the holding tank through stainless steel pipe.  All vapor associated with the unloading procedure is vented back to the truck with no release to

the atmosphere.  A pressure relieving system is in place to release pressure in unloading lines to a scrubber.   The tank sits within a concrete containment dike which is inspected annually.  Sensors are located within the unloading and storage areas that will activate automatic shutoff vales at the tank and shut down unloading and distribution pumps in case of leaks.  These sensors as well as other equipment are calibrated frequently.


The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The propylene oxide system complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and all applicable state codes and regulations.  The process equipment is designed and constructed in accordance with strict engineering standards. The unloading hoses are not pressurized, other than to equalize pressure between the tank and the truck during the unloading process.  Hoses are checked for leaks prior to unloading by visual inspection and pressure testing.  Certified operators are trained to familiarize themselves with the emergency shut off system associated with the dedicated propylene oxide trucks which would stop a discharge should something occur.  

Unloading procedures for the propylene oxide are in place to assure all emergency equipment is functional prior to unloading and that the pumps and systems are leak free.  Carriers have dedicated propylene oxide trailers that have manual shut off valves, excess flow valves, and other emergency shutoff devices that can be activated on the way out of the area to stop the flow.  

All operators are certified in the unloading operation and are required to stay within 25 feet of the truck while unloading is taking place.

The five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental release events over the past five years involving propylene oxide that have had on-site or off-site impacts.

The Emergency Response Program

Aqualon communicates regularly with the community responders and plant employees pa

rticipate in the Local Emergency Planning Committee.  In the event of an emergency involving the propylene oxide system, it is our policy to notify the Sheriff's Office through which emergency responders can be activated.  Preplanning has been completed.  Emergency drills are performed regularly.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

This facility is in compliance with the local, state, and federal standards.  This facility continues to look for ways to improve and update Safety Programs.
